story.storybody:
Hey, guys. What's up?

Just thought of dropping by and letting you know that an ex-Army chief from Australia, David Morrison, is not okay with you saying 'hey guys'.

You read that right. Morrison, who is the chairman of the Diversity Council Australia, has launched a campaign that lists out a series of words that should ideally not be used at a workplace (or elsewhere).

Also Read: 'Manbun' was the most unnecessary word of 2015; guess which was most useful?

"These are little things but a lot of the research done by the diversity council has shown these tap drips of exclusive language, gender-based language, or inappropriate language has as much deleterious or disadvantaged effect as something where you're saying something blatantly inappropriate to another human being," Morrison was heard telling ABC news.

Also Read: Women use polite words, men most likely to swear and abuse on social media

While a YouTube video for the same goes on to highlight some rather valid points like the usage of terms like 'feisty' and 'bossy' for women who dare to have opinions, Morrison's logic about not using the word 'guys' due to its gendered connotations is being hailed as taking it "a step too far".

There is no denying the fact that Morrison makes a very valid point about not using words like feisty, bossy, girls or gay at a workplace, but his stand on the term 'hey guys' (which, by the way, was kinda, sorta considered pretty gender-neutral until now) caught the interest of even Australian Foreign Minister, Julie Bishop, who, according to Mashable, believes, "I don't think we should try and interfere with the freedom of speech in this country to a point where people are too concerned about day-to-day conversations."
